componenttext: Good morning. And as you all know, we're webcast today, and I want to thank everybody for coming, a lot of familiar faces. We appreciate your interest in the company, and we thank you for your participation today. First thing I'd like to do is just introduce a few people so you can get to know a few of the folks from the company that are here, both presenting and not presenting. So not in the middle of our presentations, but certainly after that, get a chance to catch them and ask them some questions.First of all, I'll show you -- I won't do that just yet, but I want to introduce Dave Joos who will be leading the event today. Dave, of course, is our CEO. And then right over near Dave is John Russell, who's the President and Chief Operating Officer of Consumers, will be talking with you today. In addition, Bill Garrity, who is the Senior Vice President for both Electric and Gas Supply, and I know a lot of you have good questions for him because I've heard about some of those already, Bill. So just to boost them up for you. Proposes to boost them up for up. Maureen Trumble, who is our Smart Grid Director, and I know that's an interesting subject to many of you. She'll be speaking today. And also with us in the back here is Dan Malone, who's the Vice President for Customer and Energy Operations, important fellow to us. Laura Mountcastle, she's right in the back, great. Everybody knows Laura, Vice President, Investor Relations, and Treasurer for the company. Phil McAndrews is outside, but Phil is Director for Investor Relations. And then, of course, we have Glenn Barba back here in the corner. He is our Vice President, Controller and Chief Accounting Officer, keeps us all straight. And Amy Conrad, Amy is outside, I think, right now. She's part of the Investor Relations group. You'll get a chance to see her maybe a little bit later. So let me do always the fun part, but I would like you to take a look at this little more carefully and it simply says that this presentation contains forward-looking statements. They are subject to risk and uncertainties. They should be read in conjunction with the forward-looking statements and the information, as well as the Risk Factors section of the CMS Energy and Consumers Energy Form 10-K for this year ended December 31, 2009 as filed yesterday. I'm sure you all have copies of that. The presentation also includes non-GAAP measures when describing CMS Energy's results of operations and financial performance. A reconciliation of each of these measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measure is included in the appendix and posted on our website. So you'll see that in the books that you have in front of you, those of you that are with us today and those of you on the webcast, check the website.We expect 2010 reported earnings to be about the same as adjusted earnings. Reported earnings could vary because of several factors, and we're not providing reported earnings guidance reconciliation because of the uncertainties associated with those factors. So thank you for your patience there. Here's the order of what we'll do today. Dave will be up right now to introduce and cover some of the key aspects of where the company has come from recently and where we're going. And John Russell and Bill Garrity and Maureen Trumble on the subjects that I just mentioned earlier, and then I'll come up to wrap up with a financial overview. And then we'll take your questions at the end. So you'll note that you have a very lovely bright green pen. I don't know if it's a good sign or a bad sign. We normally don't give things out, but our gift to you for being with us for many years so you can make notes for your questions later in the day. And I'll turn over to Dave. Dave?

componenttext: Thank you, Tom, and let me add my welcome to all of you here in the room and also those listening on the webcast. We had another good year at the company. I'm going to just give you a very quick overview of our ongoing strategy. As you know, it's become fairly simple. John will get into more details because frankly, he's going to talk about the utility and frankly, the utility is 95% plus of our strategy. We're not going to spend a lot of time talking about enterprises, but certainly, if you have any questions, I'd be happy to answer those at the end. Our strategy has been, for some time, operating utility assets in which we have significant investment, as you know, in a safe and excellent way, and we think optimizing those assets is the way in which utilities can perform year in and year out. We have had a strategy to focus our investments on the utility each year. We update these numbers and they get a little bit bigger this year. The next five-year window looks like about $7 billion of investment, and that has gotten about $1 billion bigger than last year because we're starting to see the front end now in our five-year projection of the coal plant investment. Fair and timely regulatory recovery is critical to the strategy that we're talking about, and that's why we focused on improving the regulatory structure in Michigan a year and a half ago. We're now into operations. The new energy law that was passed in Michigan and allows for forward-looking test to you [ph] self-implementation rates. And in fact, also decoupling, which we now have on the electric side in the business and expect to have short rate on the gas side of the business. And all those factors combined, along with, we think, a constructive regulatory environment and a constructive relationship with our regulators are going to allow us, we think, to deliver on the strategy that we've adopted. Our goal has been to grow our earnings at 6% to 8% on an adjusted basis. This year, 2009, we reported $1.26 in adjusted earnings. And I'm not going to get into a lot of details, but I'd mention our GAAP net income at $0.91 and the difference between the two almost entirely related to a 10-year old issue associated with Big Rock Point decommissioning funds. We're anticipating that we might see that result. I won't say that it's not one we're not a bit disappointed in, but we anticipated it, having seen the administrative live judge decision or recommendation late last year. We were a bit surprised with the timing the commission came out with the final order, sooner than we expected. And we opened their books and reflected in 2009. So it's 10-year old issue, it's not a recurring item and in our adjusted basis for the $1.26 a share. Just a $0.01 better than our original goal of $1.25. You'll recall back in November, those of you who were at the EEI Conference, we were suggesting it might be difficult to reach our goal of $1.25 given some of the elements of the final order and the electric case [ph] that came out at that time frame. But we were able to overcome that with some good cost control. In other measures, Tom will get into more details on those.Our guidance on adjusted earnings for 2010, $1.35 per share, is up exactly 8% from our goal last year of $1.25 and so we feel pretty good about that. We have been growing our dividend, as you know. We increased it from $0.50 to $0.60 a share for this year, and that increase gets us to about a 44% payout ratio. That's still below the industry average, we're aware of that, and our intention is to continue to increase it toward the peer average. Although, we don't expect that we'll get there quickly because the amount of time or the amount of investment we're making in the company, we're not going to rush to get to that peer average. But we want to continue to move in that direction. And also, then to generate strong cash flow and liquidity, and I think our liquidity situation is fairly good now, and Tom will talk about that as well. And our cash flow is increasing at roughly $100 million a year because of the investment portfolio that we're making. So that's an outline. Now John will get into a little bit more detail in the utility here in a minute.2007 is a few years ago, as you know, but as we prepared for the presentation, we thought the last time we did this kind of an event was in 2007. So we went back and looked at what we were talking about then. I won't spend a lot of time on this, but it's been instructive. We were dealing with a significant problem with the contract at Dearborn Industrial Generating facility. That's now solved. We were focused on regulatory restructuring. As I said, it was important to our strategy. That's now been implemented, we think, in a very constructive way. And of course, managing capital projects, that hasn't changed. And that's a lot of -- what we're focused on right now is those capital projects on a go-forward basis.The environment, the business environment overall, some positive, some negative. I would say most of these have changed in a positive direction. The ones that haven't, of course, the Michigan economy and the U.S. economy, frankly, struggled since that time, and that has had some effect on electric supply and demand. But cost of natural gas, cost of construction, a lot of other things have moved in a positive direction. Maureen's going to talk a little bit more about technological innovations. Our business tends to move a bit slowly in that regard, as you know. But we are seeing technological innovation in the Smart Grid area and Smart vehicles, plug-in hybrid vehicles, and we think that's going to have a positive impact on the company over time.The investor issue we hear the most about, people ask me, "Why are you guys trading at a discount?" And my answer is, we shouldn't be trading at a discount. We don't think over time, we think we should shrink that discount. But the kinds of issues that come up are the Michigan economy has struggled more because of the auto industry. We're not heavily focused on the auto industry anymore, but there's certainly that perception. We think the Michigan economy has hit bottom and is starting to show some signs of improvement, particularly on the industrial side, and I think we'll see that here in the coming quarters. The response to that has been to try to somewhat alleviate the impact of the economy through the regulatory restructuring. We have a tracker now on uncollectible accounts, and we have surcharges in place for our renewable energy efficiency programs that are actually positive from a cash flow perspective. So we think the structure that's in place sort of mitigates that. But obviously, our life would be easier if the economy was stronger. Our balance sheet continues to be a bit leveraged at the parent, about a $1.8 billion in parent company debt. We could certainly pay that debt down, and it's our intention to do that somewhat slowly over time. But given today's environment and our opportunity to invest in the utility, we simply don't think it's economically efficient to take a lot of our excess cash and use it to pay down that debt quickly, but rather, to invest it in utility. And our dividend payout ratio is still discounted a bit to the peers, but we're moving in that direction as we just talked about.For 2010, our major priorities are fairly simple and they haven't changed a whole lot, achieved [ph] our financial objectives. And I just talked about the $1.35 a share in earnings. Our cash flow forecast, Tom will go over in more detail, and to maintain our coverage ratios and our overall debt level. Continue to focus on employee safety and operational performance, you'll see this on every slide every year, I suspect, because that's what we think the fundamental of the companies are. And to execute our investment plan, including making sure that we get timely recovery of our investments in the utility, and we continue to believe that the regulatory structure and relationships will support that. National energy policy and environmental issues, boy, they've been up and down, haven't they? It's difficult to tell right now exactly what's going to happen in Washington. I certainly don't forecast any significant movement on carbon legislation this year. Although, Senator Reid mentioned that he wants to try to get something done. That was a bit of a surprise. We do see some movement in the EPA, although, I think that process is going to be long and drawn out. So we're continuing to watch it. We were expecting and continue to plan for some sort of long-term cost of carbon in our overall plan. Bill Garrity can address that a little bit more. But nothing dramatic, in our view, that's going to affect the company here in the coming years. And then finally, our balanced energy initiative, and we make a bit of a caveat here, with or without the coal plant. Many of you are aware, I think many of you were surprised that we were able to get a permit to build a new coal plant in December. Certainly, not a lot of those being issued nationwide these days. We continue to believe that, that makes sense for the state of Michigan. But our plan hasn't been based on just building a new coal plant and frankly, there are a number of hurdles they'd get over before we are going to move forward with the construction of a coal plant. We have a permit, we expect it will be appealed in the courts. That's likely to take a couple of years to get resolved. We'll be filing a certificate immediate [ph]  This year and have to resolve with the commission whether it still makes sense to go forward with the coal plant. So a lot of detail. We're only over the first major hurdle here in the coal plant. But the point is, I don't want people to get overly focused on a coal plant because the initiative all along has been a balanced one. We have lots of investment opportunities and whether we end up building a coal plant or don't end up building a coal plant, we don't think it has a dramatic impact on our future plans here. So I just want to highlight that. With that, let me just end. I've got a cast of characters here, over a lot of detail on this and I'll be back to answer questions at the end of the presentation. Thank you.

componenttext: Good morning, everyone. What I'd like to do is go through the Utility update with you. This our going forward strategy. This is a strategy I think you're familiar with, and something that we've had for several years now. It's clear, it's consistent. When you look at the strategy, it's built on the foundation which is safe and excellent operations. Everything we do with this strategy is based on that. And if we perform that well, we're able to make the Utility investments that you see, which provide value to our customers and ultimately provide value for the regulators, which enable us to continue to make the investments and achieve the overall consistent financial performance Dave talked about. What I'd like to do today between me and the others here is, that we'll go through each of these sections with you to show you we're performing.To begin with, let me show you what some of the highlights that have occurred over the past year. Operational improvements, I'll show you some graphs in a minute to show we are making good operational improvement. We established targets back in 2006, what I called breakthrough goals between 2006, for us to achieve outstanding performance in 2012. I'll give you an update on those in just a few minutes. We just completed a restructuring of the Consumers Energy of the Utility. We reduced our workforce by about 5%, and that was completed at the end of last week. The economy continues to be a challenge. The weather, Dave Joos used to refer to this as the summerless summer which, I think, is exactly what happened in Michigan. We didn't have much of a summer, so we're challenged there. Implementation of energy legislation, the law was passed in the fall of 2008. Last year, we had our first full cycle working through the legislation and through the regulatory components to have the implementation of the law. And in my belief is, the regulators did what was intended in the energy legislation. And I'll show you a quick evaluation how I've graded that out based on the legislation and based how the regulators have implemented it. We did receive an electric Rate Order at the end of last year. Some key components there, we've talked about it with you last night. But some important pieces here are the key outcome to the cases full decoupling. That's decoupling for energy optimization, decoupling for the economy and decoupling for weather. So an important piece for us to eliminate the uncertainty of those variables, particularly in Michigan. We did receive an uncollectible tracker. That's something we've asked for, for many years. We received that on the electric side of the business to mitigate some of the uncertainty of uncollectibles with the Michigan economy. And then finally, and you'll hear from Maureen Trumble today, full recovery of the Smart Grid investment. It's something the commission is very interested in and something we think we can capitalize on in an approach to help provide value to our customers, while advancing our technological systems. The challenge we had, though, is that the final order was less than our self-implementation. It's a bit of old news now based on the earnings, but we were able to pull some operational levers, do some cost management to be able to make that our target. The good news for you, though, is that what is in that final order is what we've planned on for 2010. So going forward, our plan [ph] matches what the commission gave us as far as the electric rate case. Big Rock decommissioning was a surprise to us. Without a lot of detail, this has to do with a refund of $86 million, plus interest, for a surcharge that was on our bill for the Big Rock, which is a nuclear plant we had, Big Rock decommissioning surcharge during the freeze period. And the freeze period occurred with the first energy legislation in Michigan. When that surcharge was completed and ordered to come off the bill prior to energy legislation, we removed it from the bill and took those proceeds for general purposes. That was discussed with the commission. It was also something that we filed a tariff with the commission that was approved. I'm personally disappointed in this order. We're evaluating all options now, including appeal. So this is something that we'll continue to look at and see what happens in the future on that. And Dave talked about the clean coal plant. Bill Garrity is going to talk more about it, but I am proud that we did receive the air permit for the clean coal plant. What I'm most proud about, though, this is the best-in-class coal plant. You hear people talk about carbon neutral. This impacted this plant with the five units that we will shut down if we proceed and two more potentially that we may end up retiring based on their performance. This will be a carbon negative outcome. And I have not seen that in the industry yet. What I've seen is carbon neutral, but the efficiency of the new coal plants and the retirement of the older coal plants, the carbon output will be less than it was before we entered into this. So I'm pleased with that piece. Bill's going to get into more detail with you as we move forward. Let me now talk to you about some of the components of the strategy. And I'll start with the base, which was safe and excellent operation. As we established the targets in 2006, we can see here employee safety. For us, this is the most important thing that we do in the business. And I know this is a financial meeting, but without safety, we can't run our business. We've got a great partnership with a union, union leadership and our leadership of the management team to reduce incidents by 47% since 2006. Now we've got a long way to go. When you look at the 2006 number, we were in fourth quartile in the industry. And just to put things in perspective, we measure safe and excellent operations against all of our peers. We do a lot of benchmarking. It's the way we can determine whether we're performing or not. So far, we've been able to move with the performance in 2009 in the second quartile performance. So a lot of great progress has been made by the employees, but we still have a long way to go to get the first quartile to match our target. Productivity is another breakthrough goal we established in 2006 to increase productivity by 40% by 2012. And you can see we made a pretty good jump in 2009. We're up to 14% and we still have ways to go there, but we are moving that in the right direction, too.Reliability, on the distribution side of the business, you can see a 26% improvement. This is the lighter side of the business, minutes of interruption. Even though this graph looks like we made significant progress, we're still in fourth quartile. We do have issues that we need to improve on the distribution reliability of this business. Our frequency is first quartile, which is the number of events that occur, but as far as the minutes of interruption, the duration, we're still in fourth quartile. But we will continue to move this and improve it for customers because this is what drives value. On the generation side of the business, you can see here EFOR [Equivalent Forced Outage Rate], a standard measure in the industry for reliability. We've improved it by 39%. You see, we've kind of leveled off between 2008 and 2009, and that's intentional because with the air permits that we've received, we're making investments in our largest, newest units. And our newest units are far better than the 5.5% EFOR. But the smaller, older units that we may retire in the future, we're limiting our investment on those units because if they are retired, doesn't make a lot of sense to put the money into it and make the investments. So we're going to see that levelized over the next couple of years, but that puts us at about the average, a little bit higher than the average as far as the industry.Cost management, something we focused on every single day to enable our customers to have the best value they can. This is a five-year average on gas and a six-year average in the Electric business. These are generally all the O&M costs, including pension, overhead, A&G [ph] and so forth. You can see from the charts there, we were at the top of the second quartile. Now we moved into the bottom of the first quartile. So we are pleased that we're removing that in the right direction, aggressively managing cost and one thing we're proud to talk about and we tell the commission often is, that our A&G [ph] costs are the lowest in the country, despite the fact that Tom gave away a free pen.How will we keeping our rates competitive? This is how we do it. I won't go through all of these with you, but the first one is probably the most important. Many years ago, we converted to Western coal versus Eastern coal, that has saved our customers opportunity. If we would have burned Eastern coal versus Western coal, our customers would've paid about $1.5 billion more in fuel costs than they do today. So a significant change, and I think most of you are familiar with it. Coal costs are about $58 a ton. Western coal is about $12 a ton. Now the transportation costs are higher getting the Western coal to Michigan. However, this is a significant savings for our customers. You can see the other things here that we've done, between healthcare and cost-sharing and pension and so forth. And by the way, the defined pension program is for all of our employees, including our union employees. And then finally, the utility restructuring, which I want to talk about briefly. Back in 2007, when I combined the Electric and Gas Utilities into one, we reduced the work force by about 2.5%. We did and I called a selective basis here, which is a little unique for our company, a little unique for Michigan and probably a little unique for the industry. What that meant is, that we offered a voluntary separation package of about half a year's salary. If employees were interested in it, they could tell us they were interested in it. Historically, what happened at the company, if you were most senior, the most senior person, you'll receive that package. That's not the way we did it this time. If your job wasn't going to be eliminated or if we couldn't do the job without you, we didn't give you that package despite the fact that you were the most senior person. And that made sense to me because just because somebody's the most senior and a little bit older than somebody else, doesn't make a lot of sense for us to pay them to leave if I want them to stay. And that was a change in 2007 that we did, and it was very effective. People left that wanted to leave, and we were able to let them leave and those that stayed, we also wanted them to stay because they added value to us. We did the same thing again in 2010, but for different reasons. 2010 was in the consolidation of the industry or the utility, it was an impact of the economy in Michigan. We're seeing a couple of things happen. We think the economy, the recession we're experiencing now is cyclical, but also structural. And so we need to look at the workload and balance the workload with our workforce. We've reduced contractors, we've shifted crews around the state, we've insured as much flexibility as possible with our workforce, which I appreciate all the employees doing all that they can to continue through this process. But we still had an excess of work and excess of resources compared to the work. So we went through, again, on the salaried side of selective basis. In 2010, just last month, we also affected the union employees on an involuntary and a voluntary basis. The net change was about 5%, and you can see there the two restructurings reduced our workforce by about 530 people. We're going through that change now. I expect it will make us more productive in the future and balance our workforce to the work load.Let's switch up to another side of the pyramid, capital investment, utility investment. This is the criteria that we go through that all capital investments that we make at the utility go through this criteria. And it's something that we've used for several years now, and it's really helped us prioritize where our investments need to be. And this is the criteria we use, as it reduces O&M costs. And I think you're all familiar with $1 invested in capital costs our customers about $0.15. $1 invested in O&M costs our customers $1 in that first year. So if we can invest capital to reduce O&M, it saves our customers money as long as there's value oriented to that capital. Supply cost, we've done that, we've talked about the $1.5 billion savings in Western coal, and you can see the list here. There's an add value to customers because it provides service to customers, because it improves our competitive position and ultimately, there are some costs that we have to spend based on mandatory spending. Clean Air Act and other things like that are required. We will do it regardless if it's the most efficient thing to do or not. But this is the criteria we use, which ensures that our investments that we have our rigorous, and we use great discipline in making those investments. This slide, I think all of you are familiar with. This is the rate base slide. I'm not going to go through it because you are familiar with it. But I do want to make a couple of key points. If you look at the right-hand side of the slide, it shows the change from around $6 billion to $7 billion. And Dave mentioned the primary drivers for that, a check there, is the new clean coal plant. But also, there's a significant investment, about a quarter of a billion dollars increase in renewable energy from the last time you saw this and about $400 million in environmental compliance cost. Those are the big changes that have occurred over the last, for this five-year horizon compared to last five-year horizon. But as Dave mentioned, we have a long process to go and Bill's going to show you the various steps that are still required for the new clean coal plant. But if we wouldn't, if we didn't move ahead with a new clean coal plant, we have an abundance of opportunities to invest in the utility. And you can see there on the grayed out box several opportunities in the Gas business, electric reliability, electric generation, plus what's not even on here is taking those older plants that we committed to shut down if we build a new plant and make sure they're in compliance with the Clean Air Act. And so there's other investment opportunities there also. So a lot of opportunities for us to invest in both sides of the business.Can the customers afford it? This is an issue that we struggle with everyday that's why we're in the first quartile of cost management, and we look at every single dollar that we spend as we need to ensure we add value to our customers. What I've done here in a very simplistic way is separate Electric and Gas and have broken them down into two buckets, one is fuel and one is rate base. And you can see historically from 2006 to 2009 what the change was for electric cuts in the rates for fuel and base rates and what we expect them to be in 2009 through 2012 with what our plan has today. Base rates would go up about 3%, almost 1% of that is renewable energy and energy optimization surcharges. And the reason I mention that is, that if customers are taking advantage of energy optimization, they should see their bill decrease. So the average rate, they won't see the increase of average rates. They'll be able to see less dollars paid from their pockets to us because they're taking advantage of it. I think energy optimization offers us a great benefit for our customers and one worth investing in. On the right side of the slide, you'll see a little different story at the Gas business. The Gas business, the increase is about flat from 2006 through 2009 and then continues to be flat based on our expectation for gas prices in 2009 to 2012. But on the bottom panel there what's important is our competitive position. We continue residential rates on Electric or about 7% less than average in Michigan, so below average. And on the Gas side, we're extremely competitive when we think nationally because of the storage that we have. So this is something that we also carefully monitor to make sure that it is affordable and add value to our customers.Let's move up the triangle to regulatory. This is our strategy with the regulators in Michigan. It's one that's been very consistent for the past several years. We need to be able to provide reliable and competitive price energy to our customers. They need to have good service. They need to expect value from us, and we need to deliver that. We also see, and I think the commission sees, the value of having healthy utilities in Michigan. Michigan had struggled over the past couple of years with the major bankruptcies of some auto companies, and they see it's important to have businesses be successful and be healthy in Michigan. And what we believe is important is the cooperative process. The commission doesn't want surprises, we don't want to be surprised and we work with them in a cooperative manner. This is what I'd mentioned earlier, how legislation works and how we're doing against legislation, as far as the regulatory side. And what I've done is just taken the liberty to grade out some of the -- first of all, identify some of the key components in the legislation and you can see those there from energy efficiency to renewable energy to forward-looking tests year and so forth. And then what I've done is, not only we've had a full cycle of regulatory impact on that loss, how we ended up doing. And you can see that, I think from our company's standpoint and from the Public Service Commission, not speaking on their behalf, but I think they have implemented energy legislation as it was intended to do, as intended the law when it was written. And you can see there most of the year, renewable energy, the surcharges are in place, we're moving forward, energy optimization, there's a cap on retail access, file and implement ratemaking, all those things are progressing. I have graded two of those in yellow, one is projected test year. What the Commission did in their order with our electric rate cases spoke very clearly about the importance of projected test year. The only thing is, we saw some actions that didn't necessarily align with their words. There were some contracts we had with our union employees in place that required us to increase their salaries, and yet, the Commission used the negative surcharge for some of those. So it's kind of hard to balance that, but the rest of it I'm very comfortable with. Certificate of Need process, we haven't done it yet. We haven't gone through it, Bill is going to talk about that in a minute, nor has the Commission. And decoupling, I'm pleased with. So I think the Commission has done everything that was intended by the law and moving it in the right direction.This is my last slide, just to give you regulatory update. Most of you are curious, of all the things that are going on with the regulator, this shows, I'll start at the top, the gas rate case we self-implemented, $89 million in November, final order is due the second quarter of this year. Electric rate case, you can see we filed at $178  million, we'll self-implement in July and a final order in the first quarter of January. Show cause is one I don't think we've talked a lot about. The Commission asked us to show cause why in two years, we underspent a tracked item. Our position on that was forestry and fossil fuel, our position is we have overspent on the cumulative basis through 2006 through 2009. For all of those years combined, we have overspent what they wanted us to track. And that's something that we're in the process of working through right now and the ALJ's position will be out in April, I wish I could tell you what others think about this show cause, but no intervenor testified in this case. So that's a bit unusual. It was just us and nobody else show up. File electric decoupling, that's something you should know we'll file after the year to align and true up the decoupling from the previous year. And then the clean coal plant, I'll turn that over to Bill. There is an MPSC meeting today that has to do with the 2007 PSCR [power supply cost recovery] reconciliation. It's not out until 1:30, but I just -- we're all here today, I want to give you a heads up that's on the agenda today. So with that, let me turn it over, the certificate of Need, I'll leave you with that. Bill's going to talk about the Balanced Energy Initiative and he can go into details of what many steps we have to go before we actually file the certificate of Need and to build the clean coal plant. So with that, Bill Garrity, Senior Vice President of Electric and Gas Supply.

componenttextpreview: Thanks, John, and good morning. The Balanced Energy Initiative was developed in 2007 as our comprehensive long-term energy resource plan. It has been designed as both a balanced and diverse plan, as well as to meet the Michigan standards for renewable ene
componenttext: Thanks, John, and good morning. The Balanced Energy Initiative was developed in 2007 as our comprehensive long-term energy resource plan. It has been designed as both a balanced and diverse plan, as well as to meet the Michigan standards for renewable energy and energy efficiency. 2/3 of our new resource plan comes from new renewable energy efficiency and demand management programs. The other third comes from the Zeeland natural gas facility that we added to our operating portfolio in 2008 and our new clean coal plant. I'll be providing some status on our renewables and energy efficiency programs that were approved by the MPSC last year, as well as an update on the new coal plants. Maureen will be providing some perspective on our demand management programs next. Maintaining a balanced portfolio and diversity of fuel supply are probably the most key principles of the BEI. As illustrated in the upper left pie chart, our current portfolio is well balanced and consists of about 1/3 coal capacity, 1/3 natural gas capacity and the remaining third spread out over nuclear, oil, pumped storage, purchases and existing renewables on our systems.Our portfolio is less dependent on coal than the Midwest ISO, depicted in the upper right pie chart, which is the market we operate in. We intend to maintain a well-balanced portfolio in the future as exhibited in the lower pie chart. As that chart shows, including our new coal plant, retirement of a number of our oldest coal facilities, expansion of renewables and the demand-side management programs I mentioned, by 2018, the portfolio will be about 1/4 coal, 1/4 natural gas, 1/4 other existing generation facility and 1/4 renewables and demand side. Overall, we believe this represents an effective risk management strategy for our portfolio.As Dave mentioned, when we were here in 2007, we had just announced plans to construct an 830-megawatt coal plant at our generating complex near Bay City, Michigan. The plant is an advanced supercritical pulverized coal design and will use proven state-of-the-art technology in all aspects of its operations, including the latest and the best available technology to control emissions. There is very strong community support for the project and it represents a significant economic boost for Bay County and for Michigan, including construction and operating jobs as well as expanded local property tax base. With a projected service date of 2017, ownership of about 300 megawatts of the total capacity is assumed to be allocated to municipal entities and other interested parties, resulting in about 500 megawatts dedicated to our use. In a significant development along the way, as John mentioned, the Michigan Department of Environmental Quality issued an air permit for the plant on December 29, 2009.Besides being an important component of a balanced portfolio, we continue to believe that coal will be a significant factor in U.S. power generation in the future. Coal is the most abundant natural resource in the U.S. and 50% of America's, as well as Michigan's electricity is produced from coal. The new facility will eventually replace a number of our oldest less efficient coal plants. The new plant will be carbon-capture ready and is designed to accommodate the installation of carbon capture and sequestration equipment when this technology becomes technically and economically feasible. In addition, coal is a significant factor in helping to mitigate market price volatility and risk and the BEI capacity mix will reduce the fleet's over all environmental footprint moving forward.As this chart illustrates, our emissions of sulfur dioxide, nitrogen oxide and mercury have all been steadily declining since the late 1990s and will continue to decline substantially as we continue to implement the BEI. By 2018, the emissions from our portfolio will decline by as much as 80% to 90% from today's levels. As we've mentioned, we received the air permit in December last year, covering the first two milestones listed on this chart. But as the timeline indicates, we indeed have a long way to go. Our next big step is to file a Certificate of Necessity with the Michigan Public Service Commission, under the new process that was established by the 2008 Michigan energy legislation. This will be a very challenging process and we expect the CON case will be heavily contested, particularly since we face uncertainty and indeed differences of opinion associated with Michigan's economy and associated electric demand, future commodity prices, primarily natural gas and future emission control and regulation and cost. It is very hard to prevent the outcome of the CON process and we will not move ahead with the coal plant if the commission doesn't improve the CON, along with cost recovery for the plants being retired. However, the BEI, as I mentioned, is a comprehensive plan and a flexible plan, It identifies other viable alternatives as well, including life extension for existing fleet and/or additional natural gas capacity, if we don't move ahead with the new coal plant.Moving on to the single largest capacity component of the BEI, as I showed in that first pie chart in the first slide, our renewable energy plant was approved by the MPSC last year and we implemented an $80 million renewable surcharge last fall. Our plan is designed to meet Michigan's 10% renewable energy standard and the requirement to install 500 megawatts of new renewable capacity, which will be predominantly wind by 2015. We currently provide about 4% of our energy requirements to existing renewables on our system and our plan is to meet the incremental energy and new capacity requirement by building 50% and entering into power purchase agreement for the other 50%.The 2008 Michigan energy legislation also established a Wind Energy Resource Board to identify the best wind potential zones throughout Michigan. Based on the Board's filing, the MPSC was also charged with designating a primary wind zone, at least one primary wind zone, in order to facilitate expedited transmission upgrades associated with that zone. Michigan's Thumb region on the east side of the state was designated as that primary wind zone. And the ITC Transmission Company will have the opportunity to build new transmission in this area to accommodate substantial wind energy expansion. This could represent on the order of $500 million in new transmission being built by ITC.Consumers Energy will focus on the west side of the state initially for new generating facilities. Since in that area no new transmission is needed, there is excellent wind potential in that area and this will facilitate obtaining the current Production Tax Credit by 2012. Our intention is to move east to the Thumb region as new transmission becomes available.Our new facilities in the Thumb on the east side will be named the Cross Winds Energy Park in Tuscola County, Michigan, the west side, the Lake Wind Energy Park in Mason County, Michigan. We are already working on evaluating the results of our turbine generator solicitation to support our overall development plan and of course, with the potential of a federal renewable portfolio standard in the future, that can require additional wind capacity by 2020.On the power purchase side of renewables, the other 50% that I mentioned to complement the 50% of self build, we have already solicited for about 260 megawatts of new renewable energy purchase agreements, with about 10 megawatts of new contracts already in place and approved by the Commission. We are well along in evaluating bid responses for the next 250 megawatts, and we have an excellent set of proposals to choose from. We expect to issue another major solicitation in 2011.Moving on to demand side, the Commission approved our six-year energy optimization plan and levelized surcharge of about $90 million in May of last year. A number of residential and business programs were implemented shortly after that and overall customer demand or overall customer response has been excellent since then. The savings results in 2009, as you can see in this table, significantly exceeded the energy savings target for 2009, resulting in a $5.7 million incentive and reduced customer costs throughout our service territory. The EO [ph] programs will be expanded in 2010 to meet a higher incremental energy savings target according to the energy legislation. We have a maximum incentive potential of about $8 million next year.Our most popular programs in 2009 included residential and commercial lighting, home furnace rebates, refrigerator and other appliance recycling and incentives for heating, air conditioning and water heating equipment. In 2010, we will continue the 2009 program and focus on the most popular ones. We will also implement a number of new programs, including an existing home retrofit program and an energy efficiency classroom program that we call Think! Energy. We plan to spend up to the spending limits established in the energy legislation, and we'll strive to exceed the electric savings targets to satisfy the Commission's rate decoupling requirements.Overall and in summary, the BEI embodies a balanced and flexible strategy for new energy supply resources. Without a dominant reliance on any particular type of capacity, fuel source or technology, we believe the BEI mitigates the significant uncertainties we face and has an integrated approach to energy supply and investment planning. And with that, I thank you, and I'll turn it over to Maureen who will talk to us a little bit about our Smart Grid Program.

componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone. As Bill said, I'd like to give an update on our Smart Grid Program, starting with an explanation of the three major components for the Smart Grid Program. The diagram shown on the left side is the enhancements and improvements to o
componenttext: Good morning, everyone. As Bill said, I'd like to give an update on our Smart Grid Program, starting with an explanation of the three major components for the Smart Grid Program. The diagram shown on the left side is the enhancements and improvements to our SAP enterprise system and other core business systems that will be required to support the Smart Grid. The middle component, the network, shows the two-way communication stream that connects the customer to the company. And on the right-hand side is the home area network and it shows the 1.8 million electric meters that we will be replacing, as well as the communication modules that we'll be installing on 1.7 million gas customers meters. 80%, as you can see here, of the total cost of implementing Smart Grid is in that middle and the right side of the diagram. So one of the things that we feel is very, very clear in this is it's important to make sure that we're thoroughly assessing and piloting and testing the equipment to make sure we're making the right choices before we begin mass deployment.Smart Grid is a customer-oriented investment. We estimate the total investment at Consumers Energy to be $920 million. It enables operational efficiencies for the company and for our customers. Some of those include reduced field trips, we're able to do certain functions remotely. It also gives us the capability to improve service reliability. Bill talked about the Balanced Energy Initiative. The Smart Grid program contributes significantly to the Balanced Energy Initiative and meeting our customers capacity requirement going forward. It enables our direct load management program or dynamic pricing program, both programs together allow our customers to make better energy decisions and control their energy cost and make better decisions as far as their usage patterns. By 2020, these two programs together are estimated to contribute nearly 500 megawatts towards our capacity requirements. Smart Grid also provides customer value through expanded energy information that we're giving to customers and giving customers the capability to control their energy usage and energy costs. It also provides a good return for our customers.I know some of you in this room have toured our Smart Services Learning center, which we're very proud about. It opened in late 2008 and it serves two primary purposes: One is the demonstration facility; and the other is testing. We've had nearly 2,000 people tour the Smart Services Learning Center, that includes legislators, regulators, major customers, major vendors in the industry and media and several other groups as well. One of the major benefits we see is it helps customers to better understand the benefits that Smart Grid will enable and it also makes all of that technology much more realistic and understandable when customers can actually see the components involved. Looking at the diagram, I'll start with the blueprints at the bottom. Looking at the bottom right-hand corner of the slide, you'll see our demonstration facility in the Smart Services Learning Center. One side of the room has the customer home of the future, the other side has the utility of the future. Moving counterclockwise on the slide, you'll see in the upper right quadrant is our Michigan Public Service Commission Chairman is touring the home of the future. And here he's learning a bit more about some of the programs that Smart Grid will enable and actually seeing some of the devices. And we feel that this has been one of the keys to the relationship we built in working with the Commission. And as John talked, it helped as far as our full recovery of our investment through 2009 on the electric side, totaling $46 million.Continuing to move counterclockwise, the top left corner, you'll see what is the utility of the future. And this is the area where we demonstrate with our SAP prototype environment. We can actually show we can remotely read customer meters. We also show how we can enhance service reliability with outage response. And then continuing again on the lower left quadrant of the diagram here, is what's one of the most important segments of our Smart Services Learning Center, our testing area. And here's where we really rigorously testing the meters, the communications equipment, the equipment that will go in the customers home, as far as intelligent communicating thermostats and so forth. It's only after we rigorously tested the equipment there that then we can continue assessment by moving it into the demonstration facility and continue to evaluate it there.We have continued to position ourselves as fast followers. We're not the first in the industry to deploy Smart Grid. We're learning from the industry, we're watching other deployments. We have said we will not be the first to deploy any significant equipment of any vendor. We're continuing to assess. We're assessing seven different AMI Smart Grid vendors in our assessment facility. What some of the things that we're looking at there is we're focusing on the components, we're focusing on interoperability, security and future proofing, making sure that the equipment will be able to expand going forward as more home area network devices are available and deployed. From those seven vendors that we're assessing, the plan is to take three to four vendors into a pilot environment. I say three to four because we have already deployed two vendors into the field. We recently selected a third vendor and will begin deploying that within the next month or so. We anticipate that we'll have a fourth vendor that will pass our assessment criteria, but I can't say who that is, obviously, at this point and I can't for sure say that there will be a fourth vendor. As I said, they [ph] have to pass that rigorous assessment testing that we have. One of the other key things that goes into our architectural design and our overall vendor selection is security and interoperability standards. It's very costly and very difficult to change direction to match standards once you've deployed millions of meters. So one of the things that we have stated is until those security and interoperability standards have progressed and developed, we will not begin mass deployment. We're actively engaged with NIST, the Department of Energy and other leading groups, as far as helping to move these standards forward and the NIST roadmap shows that the required standards will be developed by the beginning, early in 2011, and that sits very well with our program schedule. We've had, as I indicated, a lot of people within our group that had been heavily involved. In fact, Wayne Longcore, from our program team, has taken a very active leadership role. He is working with NIST and is a member of NIST's Smart Grid Interoperability Panel, which is a 20-member guidance panel. He's also was recently named to a 12-member panel, that's the GridWise Architecture Council, and they're actually an advisory group to the Department of Energy as far as grid modernization. So we're taking the leadership role to help to move this critical work forward and helping to drive it. The next few slides will show a little bit more on some of the things that we're actually doing to test and assess the technology. We've collected GPS information on all of our customer meter locations. We then use that information to develop geospatial models for each of the Smart Grid AMI vendors that we're testing. This diagram shows a geospatial model for one of the mesh communication vendors that we have in assessment. Many of the pilots in early deployments across the country have been in more densely-populated urban environments. And a significant portion of our service territory is rural, so we feel it's very important to test this equipment in a rural environment and make sure how it will function where the meters are a little bit further apart and it makes it a little bit more difficult with trees and hills and all of the things that come in between.Once vendors have made it through our assessment in our lab facility, we actually get a little bit creative and we continue assessment in a field environment. We actually have mounted meters on the back of trucks that you can [ph] see here. We've also temporarily strapped them to poles. What we're doing is we're testing that geospatial model that we've developed. We're finding out where the vendors says that it takes so many collectors for so many meters, we're validating is that relationship really true. How do the communication patterns work? Is the communication truly circular or does it communicate better in one direction than another? What's the impact of trees and hills? We had highway abutments. We've had all kinds of interesting learnings that as we've gone forward in this environment, we're able to pick everything up and continue in different locations to test.I've talked about our Smart Services Learning Center, now I'd like to talk about our Smart Grid Technology Center. And what this is, as you heard in the Smart Services Learning Center, we're testing there performance and capability, but this center focuses on something different. We're focusing on quality and durability. We're actually doing a rigorous life-cycle test on meters and other devices. And this is really part of our risk mitigation strategy, finding out how those meters will hold up over that 20-year lifetime. It includes exposing meters in environmental chambers. We find out how they'll operate in a hot August day in Michigan and how they'll handle a cold January day in the dead of winter in Michigan. So we're really putting it through a rigorous test. We feel it's critical to test and validate, not only the performance, but also the durability and the quality of all of this equipment before we do begin deployment of 1.8 million electric meters and 1.7 million gas modules on meters.Very quickly, this shows our four pilot area territories that we've mapped out in the greater Jackson area. We've had significant learnings on vendor performance as we've gone through the pilot. We've also learned a lot about vendor support as we've gone forward. All of this truly has reaffirmed our approach that we feel that it is important to continue assessing and piloting the technology.This last slide shows our program timeline. It represents the major segments of work going forward and the incremental program cost. Our Board of Directors recently approved funding for the program through 2011. And I've talked quite a bit already about assessment and piloting, so I'd like spend just a couple of minutes talking about two other major streams of work that we have going forward over that two-year period. First of all, our systems and communications enablement. This is where we're building upon the enterprise system that we built with SAP that we implemented a couple of years ago, continuing to add the functionality required to enable Smart Grid benefits for our customers. It also includes expansion to our outage management system and other supporting systems. The first release you see there will be implemented in the middle of July of 2011. That will enable us to begin mass meter deployment beginning in January of 2012. There's been a second release that will come in the middle of 2012 and that release will give us additional functionality, as well as it will give us the capability to handle a higher volume of meters being deployed.The other major stream of work I'd like to talk about a little bit here is the two programs that I mentioned earlier, our dynamic pricing program and our load management program, we'll actually be conducting field pilots on both of those over the summer of 2010. Getting ready to kick both of those off right now. Dynamic pricing will actually have five treatment groups as well as a control group and we plan to learn a little bit more about customer motivation and acceptance of our marketing approaches, as well as multiple pricing option. With our load management program, we're hoping to learn more about customer reaction and receptivity to different marketing approaches. Other utilities across the country have deployed load management. We're taking a little bit of a different twist to it, but in addition to that, it's very important for us to understand how customers will respond in Michigan versus customers in California and other parts of the country because all customer groups can be different.Meter deployment, as you see here, begins to ramp up in January of 2012. We're going to start with a slow deployment pace, about what 150,000 meters over that first six months gives us a chance to learn a little bit more still about the technology. Also gives us an opportunity to learn more exactly how the field deployment goes and what are the learnings there so we can adjust going forward. The middle of the year, we begin to ramp up the pace and we'll begin deployment of about 4,000 meters on a daily basis. And we'll continue at that pace on average through the life of the program and expect to complete deployment by the end of 2015. Thank you very much.

The big yellow circle on the left side of this, I have been showing this one, it feels like since about 1981 but it really has only been a year or two. Remember back then, we watched sales decline over a three-year period, in total about 7%. In this period, it looks like we may be closer to 6% and if we're a little too pessimistic on this may be it won't even be that much and it's a good sign. Despite all the difficulties we face, we've been through this before and know some of the things that we need to do to work with our customers to try to help them be successful. So here's some of the protection. This is a look and I hear you talking a lot about this with others but these are some of the things that were able to do to minimize or mitigate the risk at the utility. I want to start with a circle on the right side. That's a pretty nice position to be in and we're grateful to be working with the Public Service Commission that's helpful to us on that. Go to the left side now, sales side of the story. When there's an upside that goes right back to our customers and gives them some cushion, that gives them a little bit more benefit and we still get our opportunity to earn our authorized rate of return. So the risk of mitigation here, we think is important. Now staying with the decoupling for a minute, here is an example of how it works for us in Michigan. I hope you do as well. But these are our sensitivities. So here are the targets for 2010. They're very similar to the kinds of targets that we've shown you before except for cash flow. To do the things that are important, including growing the dividend, so important slide for you to look at. componenttext: I don't know that any of that will necessarily have any legs, but it doesn't surprise me that people talking about. Obviously, maybe talk about both of them, we're at a 10% renewable portfolio standard by 2015, there was a lot of debate about what that standard ought to be, when the legislation was passed. In our case, we already had about 4%. Certainly, it wasn't a huge stretch for us to get to six. Though a lot of people thought ought to be higher. Of course, you're hearing the proposed federal standards that are higher than that. And I think some of people continuing to pressure and say, look let's do more. I would say it was carefully considered because there were arguments on the other side that say, look Michigan's economy isn't really strong right now. One sure thing, you want to drive up the price of terabyte over doing renewables to the time when renewables continued to be a little bit more expensive than what prices otherwise would be in the region. I think there will be continued debate. I don't expect to see anything happen in the near term with regard to changes in the state standard. We'll continue to watch what happens with the federal level and if something higher does happen, I think we've got the ability to implement more within the state. On the choice cap, remember when that choice cap was put into place, we were only in about 3%, maybe 4%,  folks taking choice percentage of our. We had been higher than 10 at one in point. And what we pointed out to the legislature and resonated was, look, when you have a situation where customers can come and go as they please, and the kind of gas price volatility we saw to drive that in either direction it has, it's going to be difficult for folks to invest in base load capacity whether it's on the Merchant side or whether it's on the Utility side. And eventually folks you're right, we're not prepared to completely get rid of the idea of choice, but we're prepared to limit it as 10% cap. We we're okay with that because frankly that's about the level of short-term purchases we would normally make as part of our portfolio planning, anyway. And it wouldn't preclude us from moving forward with the base load plan. There are some now because gas prices come down dramatically,, pricing and with the economy off for the summer that power prices came down and choice is now up to that cap for sensing [ph] where we ought to raise the cap. A lot of folks I talked to understand the fundamentals of this, where we knew that would happen and what has happened is exactly what was predicted and that's the reason we put this cap into place. I expect there will be proposals to raise the cap I don't expect that they'll get any traction but there will be no doubt be some debate about that. And I think the reason is exactly as we said, if you raise the cap then it's going to be difficult to invest in significant generation within the state and what has happened is totally predictable and the reason they put the cap in place in the first place. We'll have to watch this space. It's a political year, people will be talking about things like that. I don't expect much we'll happen quite frankly.

componenttext: CMS is part of a coalition that wants to make sure that we don't end up with a top-down planning and a broad socialization of cost, maybe I should just say it that way. There are folks that are proposing for example, that the fastest way to roll out renewables in the Eastern Interconnect would be to build a high-voltage overlay over the whole Eastern Interconnect somewhere between $50 billion and $100 billion worth of investments over time. And they've liked it to the interstate highway system. That maybe fast, but it isn't necessarily fair to all customers and isn't necessarily reflect the market. So some of the folks that are involved in this I would say including us are concerned that if you build that and socialized all the cost. Basically, postage stamp-type of rates if you will, that you'll work the economics. So that indeed when power from the Dakotas where the wind is 40% plus unavailability factor is going to be much more competitive than wind in Michigan or wind in offshore in the East Coast. If you ignore the cost of transmission if you roll the cost of transmission in and the folks building the wind or buying the power are paying for that incremental cost. The economics is actually maybe favorable, for in fact are masses [ph] that they are favorable to developing renewable in Michigan. And Ralph Izzo for example, he believes his math is favorable to developing offshore in New Jersey, but you wouldn't develop offshore wind in New Jersey at that expense, if the transmission costs were effectively socialized because it's going to be cheaper to buy power plant in North Dakota. On an overall cost, however, customers would pay more. Secondly, Michigan is a bit unique in terms of circumstances because even the Eastern Interconnect overlay analysis has been done so as Michigan wouldn't derive significant benefits, but of course if you socialize the costs then they pay a large share of those cost that actually came out negative in terms of the cost of transmission. So our goal is simply to say, let's make sure the people that are benefiting from significant transmission investment are the ones that are paying for the investment both though it's fair to the customers and so that it doesn't work the economics, and potentially even impede the development of renewables across the Eastern Interconnect to the benefits of a few locations. So that's the concern that we have.

componenttext: Generally speaking, other than the CON, we've not had a process in the past for pre-approval from a regulatory perspective. I’ll start the presentation with a few brief remarks about the quarter before I turn the call over to John Russell, who’ll give you an update on the business and regulatory agenda, and then Tom Webb will take you through a more detailed discussion on the financial results and the outlook for the remainder of the year.  Then we’ll close with questions and answers.
First quarter 2010 adjusted earnings were $0.38 a share, up $0.07 or 22% from 2009.  The increase was primarily due to the effect of the rate release on both the electric and gas sides of the business, partly offset by unseasonable warm weather and other items Tom will discuss in more detail in a few minutes.
For the full year we expect adjusted earnings of $1.35 a share, unchanged from our previous guide.  Although it’s old news to almost everyone, we raised our dividend 20% in the first quarter of 2010 to an annualized $0.60 a share, reflecting the confidence our board has in the business plan and the progress we’ve made over the past year.  
I’m going to turn the call over to John Russell, but before I do I want to make a few comments about the transition of leadership here at the company.  Ken Whipple, our current Chairman, has reached our mandatory retirement age and will step down from the board at our annual meeting on May 21.  Ken has been an outstanding Chairman and we’ll miss him.  Because we believe in separating the role of the Chair and CEO, I’ve decided to retire as CEO to assume Chairmanship at that time.  
Frankly, now that we’ve completed our corporate restructuring to focus on the utility, it makes sense from a continuity perspective to turn the reigns over to John Russell, who’s been the President and Chief Operating Officer at Consumers Energy since 2004.  John’s experience and leadership of the utility business makes him the ideal candidate to lead the company as we focus on our growing forward strategy.  
I know many of you already met John at various events over the past few years and will agree with me that he brings a high level of dedication and energy to the company.  John has already announced a few key changes to his senior management team that will take effect at the annual meeting or near that time as well.  We’ve been planning those changes as part of the transition, so I’m confident that the change will be seamless and allow us to continue the progress we’ve made.  Now let me turn the call over to John to discuss his priorities for 2010 in our key regulatory matters.

componenttext:
For 2010, our major priorities haven’t changed.  There are no changes in our financial objectives for earnings, cash flow and capital structure that were set out in early March.  Tom will review each of them with you in a few minutes.  Based on excellent operations, which is the foundation of our business strategy, and we will continue to focus on ways to improve our operational performance.
Our plan is to invest $7 billion in the utility over the next five years.  That will result in a rate base growth of about 7%.  We believe the regulatory structure and the Michigan energy law supports the fair and timely recovery of these investments.  We will continue to take an active role to influence national energy policy being debated in Washington which serves the best interests of our customers and our shareholders.  
Our balanced energy initiative has a two tracked approach.  Our base plan includes building a new clean coal plant.  Our other plan assumes replacing the clean coal plant with various alternative investments.  Whether we end up building a new clean coal plant or making alternative investments, we don’t believe it will have a dramatic impact on our future growth plan.  We have plenty of investments to invest in.
The contract with our unionized employees expires in June.  We have reached an agreement with the union on a new five year agreement.  It is in the process of being ratified.  The results will be known in May.
Now let me give you a brief update on the timing of a couple of key regulatory cases.  We self implemented an $89 million revenue increase in the gas rate case last November.  The staff and ALJ have filed their recommendations.  The case is ready for a final order in May.  We filed a new electric rate case in January seeking a $178 million rate increase.  We plan to self implement a rate increase in July.  
Last October, the Commission directed Consumers to reconcile the amount it had spent for tree trimming, an O&M expense, during the period 2006 through 2009.  Because the amount we spent exceeded the amount collected in rates, we continue to believe we don’t owe a refund.  The staff has recommended a refund of $27 million, whereas, the ALJ supports our position of no refund.  A final order is expected in the second quarter of this year.
To comply with the requirements of the electric decoupling mechanism, approved in last November’s electric rate order, we plan to file an annual reconciliation with the Commission in the first quarter of 2011.  We expect recovery in 2012. 
Here’s a little more detail on the gas and electric rate cases.  On March 24, the ALJ filed his proposal for decision in our gas rate case, recommending the $60 million rate increase.  The two primary differences from the $89 million the company self implemented are a lower return on equity and a lower uncollectible account expense.  The ALJ supports the sales decoupling mechanism proposed by the company with a modification to reflect weather normal consumption.  He also recommends approval of the pension and OPEB trackers.  
However, he does not support our proposed uncollectible tracker.  The final order is due no later than May 21.  The schedule has been set for the electric rate case.  We must file by June 28.  The tariffs we plan to self implement on July 22.  The staff will file its testimony on June 10 and the ALJ’s PFD will be filed on September 16.  
As Dave said earlier, our full year adjusted EPS guidance remains at $1.35 a share.  Our adjusted EPS has grown at an average rate of 8% over the past six years and our growing forward strategy, supported by the regulatory construct and the Michigan energy law, should permit us to deliver 6% to 8% EPS growth going forward.  Our current dividend payout ratio has grown over the past four years and is currently at 44%.  Now let me turn the call over to Tom to discuss the first quarter results.
